turn.text: But he's dependent upon what a jury would decide between these two psychiatrists then.

turn.speaker: edmond_a_tiryak
turn.label: Mr. Edmond A. Tiryak
turn.text: If he wants to restrain people for long periods of time as we have here... to rule in our favor here we're not talking about short term emergency situations.
The Court of Appeals mentions that.
We're talking about long term, protracted, daily use of restraints not for a treatment purpose.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Maybe the safe thing for this psychiatrist to do would be to enter an order that there's nothing more we can do for this man here, I order him released.
Is that a solution to the problem?

turn.speaker: edmond_a_tiryak
turn.label: Mr. Edmond A. Tiryak
turn.text: It might be a solution to the problem for the doctor.
I doubt a doctor would do that.
You know, we have our duties as lawyers; doctors have theirs as doctors.
And I don't think doctors would--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Then if he goes out and injures somebody after that release, then the doctor is going to be sued for having released him.
He also has a little trouble with the Hippocratic oath, too, doesn't he?

turn.speaker: edmond_a_tiryak
turn.label: Mr. Edmond A. Tiryak
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Counsel, the Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit suggested jury instructions that are appended to its opinion.
Do you approve of all three of those?

turn.speaker: edmond_a_tiryak
turn.label: Mr. Edmond A. Tiryak
turn.text: Well, first of all I think it's important to note that they didn't command the District Court to use these instructions.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That is right.

turn.speaker: edmond_a_tiryak
turn.label: Mr. Edmond A. Tiryak
turn.text: I think that the Court of Appeals felt in this case the trial court was in need of some assistance in formulating jury instructions.
Our standards differ slightly.
We've noted the standard we have in our belief.
For example, we don't think it's necessary for this Court to get to the question of whether the Fourteenth Amendment itself requires habilitation for all retarded people.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: In at least two of the three instructions the language used refers to the need for showing compelling reasons and for employing least restrictive means.
Are they standards you urge us to accept?

turn.speaker: edmond_a_tiryak
turn.label: Mr. Edmond A. Tiryak
turn.text: The least restrictive standard used in the context of prefrontal lobotomies is--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: In the context of what?

turn.speaker: edmond_a_tiryak
turn.label: Mr. Edmond A. Tiryak
turn.text: --Lobotomies, psychosurgery when they operate on your brain, is--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It's also used in connection with shackling and with failure to provide care.

turn.speaker: edmond_a_tiryak
turn.label: Mr. Edmond A. Tiryak
turn.text: --Well, Your Honor, it was an alternative ground.
Our feeling is that the primary ground on restraints that the Court of Appeals used was the correct one, the necessity standard, or they talk about essential, but we think a necessity--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But returning to my question, just to make sure that I understand your position, if we remand the case, for example, suppose we just remand it because there has been no jury trial, would you urge the three instructions on the District Court that have been suggested by the Court of Appeals?

turn.speaker: edmond_a_tiryak
turn.label: Mr. Edmond A. Tiryak
turn.text: --Well, I'm not sure that I would... I think that this is what we have been bound by the opinion, so I'm not sure it would make much difference what we--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: In other words, you would approve of the use of the language compelling need and least restrictive means?

turn.speaker: edmond_a_tiryak
turn.label: Mr. Edmond A. Tiryak
turn.text: --I'm sorry.
I realize I'm being confusing to you, Your Honor.
I apologize for doing so.
Let me try to--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What I'm trying to get at is what your standards would be.
This is a difficult question in the case for me.

turn.speaker: edmond_a_tiryak
turn.label: Mr. Edmond A. Tiryak
turn.text: --We don't feel as though the least intrusive standard is a standard that is necessary to be used to decide this case.
To the extent that the Court of Appeals has used that standard, we don't feel it's necessary.
We accept the fact that--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You don't think that's necessary.

turn.speaker: edmond_a_tiryak
turn.label: Mr. Edmond A. Tiryak
turn.text: --Yes.
It's unnecessary to decide the case, to get to those issues.
And we haven't urged them in our brief.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But do you think the Constitution requires that standard?

turn.speaker: edmond_a_tiryak
turn.label: Mr. Edmond A. Tiryak
turn.text: In the abstract... if you say something is the least restrictive alternative that is necessary to resolve the need... for example, restraints... to say that there are lesser restrictive standards that are available is another way of saying that the restraints would be necessary.
So if you look at least restrictive alternative in the appropriate way, we believe that it comes out to mean necessary.

The problem is that least restrictive alternative is a standard that can be looked at and has been looked at by courts in a variety of different ways and is susceptible to a variety of different interpretations.
That's the problem we have with the standard, and that's the reason we've just retreated, shall we say, into the necessary standard because of that's appropriate.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well I thought you said some time ago in your argument that your approach in the trial court or your submission that you took the least restrictive alternative approach.

turn.speaker: edmond_a_tiryak
turn.label: Mr. Edmond A. Tiryak
turn.text: Yes, we did.
We asked the Court of Appeals in our treatment claims to find there was a least restrictive alternative, and we lost the Court of Appeals--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And then you say you retreat from them and you take the necessity standard, is that it?

It seems to me like you've... I'm not sure I quite understand with respect to what did you tell Justice Powell that the least restrictive, least intrusive approach was not constitutionally required, or at least you weren't pressing it?
With respect to what?

turn.speaker: edmond_a_tiryak
turn.label: Mr. Edmond A. Tiryak
turn.text: --The problem is that the Court of Appeals used least restrictive in three different situations, okay.

The first, in a treatment claim, is dicta as far as we're concerned because those claims... the situation in which the Court of Appeals said you can use the least restrictive alternative, like involuntary sterilizations, are situations that have nothing to do with this case.
In the general right to treatment the Court of Appeals said there is no right to least restrictive alternative.
They said that using a least restrictive alternative approach in day to day treatment decisions would be a mess because they... so we lost there.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: edmond_a_tiryak
turn.label: Mr. Edmond A. Tiryak
turn.text: Okay.
So on that part of it we accept the Court of Appeals decision, and we'll take their standard on that.

Now, the Court of Appeals also as an alternate holding on the shackling claim used least restrictive alternative after their primary holding, which is shackles, custodial shackles, would be necessary... would be illegal if they weren't necessary.
Now, in that situation with restraints we like the necessary standard.
We think it's a clarification in a sense of the least restrictive alternative standard.
It's sort of a mess, I agree.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You're quite right.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you, gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
